After NPR's broadcast, the inspector general at Homeland Security, the agency's internal watch dog, announced he would conduct his own investigation of how immigrant detainees are treated.
His report came out this week and it confirms that detention centers violate the government's own standards.
Here's NPR's Daniel Zwerdling.
The inspector general did not investigate the beatings or the use of dogs.
Immigration officials had already ordered detention centers to stop using dogs the day after NPR's reports.

But the inspector general's findings seem to confirm what detainees and activists have been charging for years.

Justice Department write the government's official national detention standards.
Homeland Security detains hundreds of thousands of non-citizens every year at more than 300 jails and prisons across the country.
It charges most of them wit violating civil immigration laws.
They don't have anything to do with terrorism.
And the government detains thousands of other immigrants while they apply for asylum.
The standards say that all of them must be detained in safe, secure and humane conditions.
Well, the inspector general examined five detention centers and he found that none of them was meeting all those standards.
For instance, two of the five jails were infested with rats and roaches.
The ventilation system at one jail didn't work.
